Friday, January 16, 2015 at 11:39pm EST
Jason Hu updated his status.
So happy to say I'll be back in San Francisco after graduation, working for Blend Labs! I can now be your obligatory friend who works for another goddamn startup. Looking back to these past four years, I couldn't have gotten this far without the help of so many friends, mentors, and random, kind people. Brown, you're an amazing community, and I can't wait to be back for my final semester.

Friday, May 10, 2013 at 6:13pm EDT
Samantha Gates posted a link to your timeline.
1) I love when I message you the link to a silly article and it ends up on BlogDH: http://blogdailyherald.com/2013/05/10/useless-rankings-brown-ranked-thirteenth-on-list-of-happiest-freshmen/ 2) I love that BlogDH has writers who are as passionate about this place as I am: "A non-competitive ivy-league school seems like an oxymoron, but that seems to be where we go. Brown is a really happy place, in part because it feels like we can do whatever we want to do. It’s not just about open curriculum; it’s about the fact that you can just as easily experience all of Providence life or never leave College Hill; that you can just as easily go to a frat house as a RISD party; that on a given Wednesday night you could be at the sketchiest, most beloved college bar that has ever existed, or in the stacks of the Rock, writing a really great paper on Keats, or in the CIT lounge, doing whatever it is you do there (…seriously what do you do there?). Sometimes going out might actually mean “going out,” but other times it might just mean playing illicit (or non-illicit) games around Nicolas Cage movies. You can be whoever you want to be and be happy at Brown." 3) I still have your shirt <3

Tuesday, January 15, 2013 at 11:47pm EST
Megan Davis wrote on your timeline.
I thought you might appreciate some of these Subject: WRY OBSERVATIONS AND WEIRD AMBIGUITIES 1. ONE TEQUILA, TWO TEQUILA, THREE TEQUILA, FLOOR 2. ATHEISM IS A NON-PROPHET ORGANIZATION. 3. CAN AN ATHEIST GET INSURANCE AGAINST ACTS OF GOD? 4. IF MAN EVOLVED FROM MONKEYS AND APES, WHY DO WE STILL HAVE MONKEYS AND APES? 5. THE MAIN REASON THAT SANTA IS SO JOLLY IS BECAUSE HE KNOWS WHERE ALL THE BAD GIRLS LIVE. 6. I WENT TO A BOOKSTORE AND ASKED THE SALESWOMAN, "WHERE'S THE SELF-HELP SECTION?" SHE SAID IF SHE TOLD ME, IT WOULD DEFEAT THE PURPOSE. 7. WHAT IF THERE WERE NO HYPOTHETICAL QUESTIONS? 8. IF A DEAF PERSON SIGNS SWEAR WORDS, DOES HIS MOTHER WASH HIS HANDS WITH SOAP? 9. IF SOMEONE WITH MULTIPLE PERSONALITIES THREATENS TO KILL HIMSELF, IS IT CONSIDERED A HOSTAGE SITUATION? 10. IS THERE ANOTHER WORD FOR SYNONYM? 11. WHERE DO FOREST RANGERS GO TO "GET AWAY FROM IT ALL?" 12. WHAT DO YOU DO WHEN YOU SEE AN ENDANGERED ANIMAL EATING AN ENDANGERED PLANT? 13. IF A PARSLEY FARMER IS SUED, CAN THEY GARNISH HIS WAGES? 14. WOULD A FLY WITHOUT WINGS BE CALLED A WALK? 15. WHY DO THEY LOCK GAS STATION BATHROOMS? ARE THEY AFRAID SOMEONE WILL CLEAN THEM? 16. IF A TURTLE DOESN'T HAVE A SHELL, IS HE HOMELESS OR NAKED? 17. CAN VEGETARIANS EAT ANIMAL CRACKERS? 18. IF THE POLICE ARREST A MIME, DO THEY TELL HIM HE HAS THE RIGHT TO REMAIN SILENT? 19. WHAT WAS THE BEST THING BEFORE SLICED BREAD? 20. ONE NICE THING ABOUT EGOTISTS: THEY DON'T TALK ABOUT OTHER PEOPLE. 21. HOW IS IT POSSIBLE TO HAVE A CIVIL WAR? 22. IF ONE SYNCHRONIZED SWIMMER DROWNS, DO THE REST DROWN TOO? 23. IF YOU ATE BOTH PASTA AND ANTIPASTO, WOULD YOU STILL BE HUNGRY? 24. IF YOU TRY TO FAIL, AND SUCCEED, WHICH HAVE YOU DONE? 25. WHOSE CRUEL IDEA WAS IT FOR THE WORD LISP TO HAVE "S" IN IT? 26. WHY ARE HEMORRHOIDS CALLED HEMORRHOIDS INSTEAD OF ASSTEROIDS? 27. WHY IS IT CALLED TOURIST SEASON IF WE CAN'T SHOOT AT THEM? 28. WHY IS THERE AN EXPIRATION DATE ON SOUR CREAM? 29. IF YOU SPIN AN ORIENTAL PERSON IN A CIRCLE THREE TIMES DO THEY BECOME DISORIENTED?

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
The kids are generally awesome, except for the select few that I am convinced will one day overthrow the world as we know it... be prepared. And I can't knock CA weather, since it's afforded me the opportunity to actually get a tan without my hair morphing into a humidity-driven monster bent on consuming everything in its path. That made my hair sound way more intimidating than I'd really intended. You get the point. Humidity = bad. Sun = good. I would comment on your summer work except my brain pretty much went "OMG NASA OMG OMG ROCKETS OMG MOON OMG" and shut down entirely. That's a word for word transcription, of course.

Carolyn Huang wrote on your timeline.
today was a terrible day. 1. lotion spilled in my purse...pretty sure the value of my textbooks dropped about $50. i'm also scared of sticking an oily key into my laptop lock. 2. i stubbed my toe while trying to open the door. i then bled my way back to my dorm room. 3. i got two pieces of garlic bread in the cafeteria. one fell on the ground after i sat down :( 4. my friend lent me a CD and i cracked it. I then freaked out for a while before apologizing...and it had already been cracked. wasted worrying. then i saw a package. we get them everyday--jk susan does. so i cry. but today i actually did! i got chocolate chip cookies, madelines, orange bread, cranberry-orange scones, blueberry coffee cake, home, nostalgia, and LOVE. you guys are the best! thanks for being my sunshine :) now i can actually make friends... I LOVE YOU ALL! <3 Noga Feinberg Joel Infeld Miranda Adams Harlowe Wang Caleb An

Monday, May 23, 2011 at 5:48am EDT
Mya Ballin posted a photo to Jason Hu's timeline.
This is a very rough first draft for a Spanish project that I'm doing about the Americanization of Mexico (I am also writing a paper, but my teacher is a huge fan of art for some odd reason and I figured it'd be a good excuse to not write something in detail). Basically the idea was the transfer pop art to sort of Spanglish-y stuff. Not very good because I was drawing it during a choir concert (my fonts are hand drawn and SO FREAKING OFF) and the medium I'm using is pastel rather than screen printing (I'm tempted to make a screen and do it that way but that would take time away from Tapestry), but what do you think of the idea? You're one of the few artistically inclined people I know... so, yeah. I figured I'd ask. :P. Suggestions for something else? Not sure I'm 100% happy with this...

Monday, March 14, 2011 at 12:24am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Anyhow, I'm bored and wondering why my teachers are failing to grasp that nobody cares... I love my Lit teacher, but if she thinks that we're at all invested in Hamlet, she is dreaming. I just spend all of my time when we watch the movie version wondering what possessed Kenneth Branagh to bleach his hair and play a part he was 15 years too old for... also, why isn't there a single normal door in the entire castle? Yeah, I just realized that if your teacher hasn't subjected you to that movie, you'll have no idea what I'm talking about. Oh well, that's hardly new for me. I'm out of ideas for the moment, so it's your turn. Resist the urge to take two and a half months to respond. Pretty sure that in that amount of time, I could find your house and rig it to blast the Jonas Brothers into your room 24/7. Speaking of which, my neighbors are putting in a pool, which apparently involves jackhammers at 7 on a Sunday. My neighbors may soon be dead. I leave you on that note of violence...

Monday, March 14, 2011 at 12:08am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Now on to me.... Yeah, not a whole lot going on there. I'm not swimming cause my shoulder is screwed up, which is fun (dripping sarcasm here, in case internet medium does not fully communicate). I've officially concluded that physical therapists are simultaneously the nicest and most sadistic people on the entire planet. They routinely ask me to do things that I'm relatively certain are anatomically impossible, even if my shoulder was functioning. I skipped school on Tuesday to go dress shopping for Senior Ball with some of my friends, which was entertaining to say the least - like I said, Senioritis. Growing. Exponentially. And then I got to watch guys get auctioned off at our school's Mr. GQ on Friday, which is always satisfying from a feminist standpoint, though I wish that so many of them wouldn't choose singing as their talent when it so blatantly isn't.

Monday, March 14, 2011 at 12:01am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I'm going to devote an entire post to Fringe, just because you're pretty much the only person I know besides me who watches it, so I have no one to rant to. I know that the generally accepted term is Fauxlivia, but I've come to prefer "Holivia", mostly because that's exactly how I feel about her character. And I totally agree with you on: a) the fabulousness of Walter b) the immense skill it took on the part of the writers to pull off that whole parallel universe thing... too bad they had to go SCREW UP THE ENTIRE THING BY MAKING HOLIVIA PREGNANT. There, glad I got that out of my system. I believe "soap opera" is the appropriate description, too... I saw that twist coming from miles away, which is why I assumed they wouldn't go there... and then they did. Argh. If the show gets cancelled, I so don't want that to be my final impression of it.

Sunday, March 13, 2011 at 11:56pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Yes, scholarships are the new bane of my existence. How $500 is possibly going to offset any portion of my obscenely expensive college education is beyond me. If I actually recieve one, I'm tempted to spend it on shoes. Or books. Or smuggling a pygmy hippo into the country and keeping it in my swimming pool as a pet. Dear god, was that movie actually any good? I wasn't masochistic enough to go see it, so I have no idea, although what I saw in the trailer terrified me (and not in a good way). I've been making an effort to avoid the movie theater ever since one of my friends coerced me into seeing "Country Strong" with her. I *hate* country music. Greater love hath no friend than to not walk out of the theater the third time Gwyneth Paltrow started drunkenly crying. I still haven't fully recovered...

Sunday, March 13, 2011 at 11:50pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
To the whole debate thing, all I can say is: you would. Also, my mother tells me that I'm going to hell at least once a day, so don't feel too bad. For some reason, I don't have to do a Senior Project, which is nice since I can't see myself putting that much effort into one even if I did. My senioritis grows worse with each passing week. You scream "Swaziland", so I'm sure that went well. And speaking of screaming, in regards to your comments about squealing over a peacoat, you have given me no choice but to conclude that you've gone full hipster. The next time we meet, I will probably be forced to tie you to a chair and make you watch/listen to something mainstream. Of course, that would be painful to me too, but I'm willing to give for the greater good.

Sunday, March 13, 2011 at 11:42pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I was actually genuinely concerned that I wouldn't have an RRMM for this edition of "Jason and Steph's Superlong Posts Guaranteed to Piss Off All Mutual Friends" (Parenthetical Brian shout-out time!), but, blissfully, my completely deranged AP Spanish teacher saved me from a sad, rodent-less fate. She was stressed on Friday and so decided to show us an epic slideshow of cute nature pictures, an alarming number of which were of squirrels. It was designed to be comforting. It failed miserably. The rodent revolution is coming. You know it. I know it. And now I'm visualizing hordes of rodents donning uniforms, forming barricades, and singing "One Day More". I have Les Mis on the brain. I apologize for yet another musical reference you probably won't get.

Sunday, March 13, 2011 at 11:36pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
So, I'll start with a confession: my obsessive need for competition almost led me to try to beat you for the tardiness award... and then I realized that would just be ridiculously depressing. Instead, you shall receive a (semi)timely response. Although I do feel obligated to note that most bystanders probably believe that we're crazy regardless of how in or out of context our responses may be. But I digress... Making everything equate to "awesome" or "not awesome" = surefire way to make my brain automatically think of HIMYM... or Chuck. Lots of awesomeness out there. Knowing what I'm doing right now = probably not actually that hard to predict, and therefore marginally less stalkerish than might be assumed. Sleep. Eat. Pretend to do hw. Do something crazy. Drink coffee. Repeat.

Caleb An wrote on your timeline.
I sent you the poll results; it's in boolean so 1's are yeses, 2's are nos, I put the ages in for the ones that you asked for ages; if you want to find how many did X across all ages, do 1- the proportion of 0's. the command for finding matches between two groups is =SUMCOUNT((interval, "word you're looking for")*(same thing as before)

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:53am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
So, tag, you're it. Enlighten me about the goings-on of your life, be it the Big C, your poor concussed almost-Homecoming date, your latest culinary adventure, or even your latest diabolical reunion plan (On a semi-related note, I'm actually busy dusting off plans a friend and I made last year to fake our own deaths, hijack a plane, and move to Hawaii to work at a surf shop. You never know when I could need it). Also, I think the rodent moment might have to become a tradition. Bring it on...

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:50am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Well, you asked for a post or two, and I think you're getting seven... You're welcome, Brian. Random rodent moment of the month (known from here on out as RRMM): I was putting up some signs for Leadership and we saw THE FATTEST SQUIRREL EVER TO LIVE. This thing couldn't even scamper up a tree when we got close - it had to haul itself up doing this weird pull-hop thing. It was bigger than some cats I've worked with at the veterinary hospital. It could asphyxiate you while you slept. Also, I'm officially loving Disney right now. Not only are they releasing Beauty and the Beast (one of my all-time faves) from the vault just in time for the holidays, but I'm sorta in love with Tangled (the new Rapunzel movie, complete with the voice of Chuck's Zachary Levi), and I'm fulfilling my annual trip to the Happiest Place on Earth two weeks from now. Yes, I am five.

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:44am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Gah, I just hit word limit too. So irritating. I think I'm becoming conditioned to hate 1,000 character limits. Fringe: I can finally stop screaming at my television set every time Peter and Alt-livia (Bolivia? So many options...) are onscreen. I know we're supposed to be rooting for both universes, but I violently disliked her and that entire plotline. Not as much as I'm disliking the majority of what's been happening on Glee, but still... True confession: The baristas at the Starbucks next to my high school have known my name and drink order (depending on the temperature) for two years. You want to talk coffee issues... And if you ever actually purchase/wear a fedora, I will hunt you down and kill you with a pimp cane. I don't care that we're friends. Fedoras are the sign of the devil. Besides, I think your hair might revolt against it...

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:40am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Ah, Homecoming. I think it's finally time to accept the fact that what Buffy's birthday was to her, Homecoming is to me (I don't know if in all the insanity of life, etc. you've had time to watch any BTVS, so brief explanation: for the first couple seasons, the gang would try to celebrate Buffy's b-day, and every year something would go horribly, horribly awry, until they finally just gave up on celebrating it altogether. This is pretty much where I'm at on Homecoming). Somehow, without fail, both illness and social drama always manage to rear their ugly heads around the time of that illustrious dance. I've officially given up. Sad fact: I didn't even bother to go. Alas, all those salespeople died in vain.

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:34am EST
Mark Schreiber wrote on your timeline.
i owe you an apology just put the article on google docs. lemme know what you think. i did what i could what i had but i would love input

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:31am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Yes, I too am ashamed of myself over the Very Potter Musical debacle, don't worry. And yes, I watched the sequel too. And yes, I tried to redeem some of my geek cred by going to the midnight showing of Deathly Hallows, which was completely nerdy and amazing. And yes, I've now become one of those snobby people who knew Darren Criss *before* he was on Glee. Yay for pretentious nerds! I feel your high school musical pain, though (wow, that sentence works in so many ways). My school is doing All Shook Up this year, and sophomore year they did Into the Woods. I'm not a fan of Sondheim, and they're probably not gonna get Cheyenne Jackson to drop by our school to perform the lead in this year's show, so I'm kinda saddened by the state of things. Why wasn't I here when we did Aida or Oliver, I ask you?

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:26am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
On a lighter note, let's discuss retail zombies, shall we? They should have their own spin-off of "The Walking Dead" devoted solely to the brain-dead individuals who crowd the local malls on holiday weekends and congest the walkways with their pointless window-shopping and strollers the size of hummers, impeding my Christmas shopping. I hate them all, and next time, I'm going shopping with the aid of a Zamboni and a grenade launcher. Okay, rant over. Commence the deep, soothing breathing. Ah, high school. That thing which works to impede me from making progress on The Big C. I'm suffering from early-onset senioritis, sadly, despite the fact that I really do need to maintain good grades for at least four more weeks. For the record, I wondered the exact same thing about "Jersey Thursday" the first time it was mentioned. Blissfully, it's of the athletic, not pathetic variety.

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:20am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Wow. The end of that came out looking a lot trippier than I intended. Which works, I guess. Onward. First, let's address the Big C: Christmas shopping. Oh, fine, college is probably what I was actually meaning to talk about, but I'm so traumatized from today's holiday shopping experience that the college stress has almost left my mind. Oh, nope, wait, there it is again. Basically, it's reached the point where the pressure has reached a boiling point, and I've sort of done the opposite of you: I've completely clammed up. It's literally reached the point where I will refuse outright to discuss applications with my friends. Thanksgiving was hell. If one more well-meaning relative asked me where I was going to school next year, I was going to cast myself upon the butter knife.

Monday, December 6, 2010 at 1:14am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Welcome to this month's edition of the epicsuperlonghopelesslytardy (yep, it's been used twice, it's officially a word) wall posts of despair. I was really, really hoping to prove history wrong too, if only to piss off my history teacher from last year. He was, as far as I could tell, the spawn of Satan. Also, "The Illusionist" is forever ruined for me because he looks *exactly* like Edward Norton in that movie. Yep, it's going to be one of those wacky my-brain-free-associates-like-it's-on-drugs-but-it's-not-which-makes-the-concept-of-me-on-drugs-that-much-scarier series of posts. Enjoy.

Sunday, October 3, 2010 at 12:19am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
- When I first read your complaint about tux rentals, I was sympathetic. Then I read it today after shopping for a homecoming dress (Why is it that the only thing I can't withstand peer pressure on is formal dances? Why, I ask you?) and my sympathy has sadly remained in the dressing room, along with all of the unflattering dresses and the last vestiges of my sanity. - "Where's the goddamn pesto" = what I'm going to scream the next time a classroom becomes uncomfortably silent. - Your last sentence was just funny back in May. Now, I read it, and all I can think about is Inception. - Why is everyone in college now? It messes with my diabolical kidnapping plans when there are people in LA and Davis. Maybe a roadtrip to Davis is in order... Anyhow, how are things with you? I think I've sufficiently filled the newsfeed. Also, if you're reading this, hi Brian! (What? You never know...)

Sunday, October 3, 2010 at 12:11am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Random thoughts from rereading your posts from a long time ago, in a gala- okay, it was only May. Must resist urge to full-on geek out. - I literally did the exact same thing as you for APUSH. I may have to think all of my religious views. Clearly, there is someone looking out for the crazy nerds. - You know those bouts of screaming at the tv that we talked about? I had another one during the Fringe finale. And during both of the ones since. Shockingly, they go something along the lines of: "Peter, are you completely brain dead?!?! THAT'S NOT THE REAL OLIVIA, YOU MORON?!" Thank god my family loves me, or I would have been locked up a long time ago... - The second I read your thing about a marsh, my brain immediately jumped to that line from Monty Python about the castle and the swamp. Then I visualized a ball room sinking and all these people in formal wear beating off alligators with corsages and stilettos. My mind is a scary place.

Sunday, October 3, 2010 at 12:04am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
The dress-ups for this week, which I have to do (thank you, Leadership...) are all decades, which I thought would be fine until the genius juniors picked the 70s. Seriously, you have second choice of the decades from 1900 to 2000, and you pick the 70s? The decade where everyone's sense of fashion took a ten-year hiatus? Even the freshmen had the good sense to just pick the 50s so everyone could dress like extras from the set of Grease. Good god, I just said something complementary about freshmen... I'm catching up on my viewing of Fringe, which is a great deal like taking an electric mixer to one's brains... interestingly, that may be the only absolutely disgusting thing that Fringe hasn't tried yet. The muscial episode was awesome (Not as awesome as Buffy's, but I'm not sure anyone's gonna top that. There was a song about drycleaning. Automatic win).

Saturday, October 2, 2010 at 11:57pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
In other news, I've been busy discovering a hundred and one ways to avoid doing the one thing I should be doing... the apps-which-must-not-be-spoken-of. I found a Very Potter Musical on Youtube... How had I never seen this before? It combines musicals and Harry Potter and features a vaguely gay Voldemort... it is a travesty that this had existed on the internet for so long without my knowledge. Homecoming is next week for my school, and it's a ridiculously big deal this year because our school is turning 100 years old. In other news, the school's pool is turning 57. Just saying. But, you know, the football field now has a scoreboard with a video screen that can broadcast instant playback, never mind that you can see the plays better by just looking at the game. I'm not bitter...

Saturday, October 2, 2010 at 11:49pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
My new cast of teachers may actually be the best part of this year. I have a Gov teacher who has decreed that every Thursday is "Jersey Thursday", an Honors Physics teacher who is even more anal than I am (He has a line of tape around his desk where we aren't allowed to step. I'm not even kidding. Also, a full-sized cutout of Christian Bale from The Dark Knight on the door to his supply closet with a speech bubble that says "Do Not Enter"), an AP Stats teacher whose wife is a nutritionist (he has an entire cabinet filled with food at the school), and an AP Lit teacher who has a shawl in every color of the rainbow who literally told us on Friday that the placement of every comma has a hugely important meaning. Seriously, where do they find these people?

Saturday, October 2, 2010 at 11:43pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Of course, senior year has its upsides: -All of my teachers seem to have embraced the fact that if they give seniors too much homework, we'll just drop the class instead of trying. Adios, late nights working on ridiculous history essays and bio labs. Oh, how I shall not miss you. -We didn't have a full week of school until four weeks into the school year. Gotta love going to Water World three weeks in for no apparent reason. Other than the Dippin' Dots, which I suppose should be reason enough. -I feel even *less* guilty about elbowing freshmen out of my way in order to get to class on time. -One of my teachers accidentally marked me absent, my mom got a call about me cutting... and she didn't even seem that upset. This may be the most amazing thing on this list.

Saturday, October 2, 2010 at 11:38pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Hey back at you! Why have we not talked in so long? I could offer up a list of highly implausible reasons involving kidnappings and violent carnivorous animals, but that would make it seem like I live a far more exciting life than I do. Reality: Senior year is insane. Vastly preferable to junior year, but still, you know, insane. Anyhow, insanity aside, it's very strange to realize that we're almost a quarter of the way through senior year. Every time someone mentions the word "college", I have to run away and hide under a rock somewhere. This might explain why I have no friends...

Saturday, September 25, 2010 at 4:50pm EDT
Kenny Moran wrote on your timeline.
Did you notice how the article Freeman gave us only addressed the impracticality of one type of new generation reactor, and made the blanket claim that all new generation reactors, including thorium reactors, "don't offer realistic solutions to the problems of waste and terrorism," completely ignoring the recyclability of nuclear waste and the insignificance of nuclear radiation to humans and animals? Wow, that was one hell of a run-on sentence. All these critics base their arguments off of the same societal presumptions. "The first big breeder, Fermi I, nearly exploded in Monroe, Michigan, in 1966, threatening to irradiate the entire Great Lakes region." He doesn't need to prove that a spill would have had any significant environmental impact. He just has to say "nuclear power plant explosion" and people automatically jump to the conclusion of "three-eyed fish". Ugh.

Tuesday, May 18, 2010 at 12:06am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Well, I'm six posts in (I don't count the pissy, Zac Efron-fueled one. That one was a bonus. Or just therapeutic. You decide) which is probably enough to cover your entire wall and annoy all mutual friends, so I suppose I should stop. Three more things: 1. Ironically, I like kids. I guess I just don't like those specific kids. Or, I hate trampolines. Either way, it's hilarious that you remember them. 2. I am once again on the warpath. There will be a reunion at the start of summer. If my plans are once again thwarted, I cannot be held accountable for my own actions. I am unstable, frequently over-caffeinated, and the owner of two very enthusiastic canines and a small car with a large trunk. Be afraid. You have been warned. 3. Trust me, we aren't well-adjusted members of society. The fact that I just wrote #2, and the fact that you won't report it to the authorities, clearly demonstrates that we are mentally unstable. And all the more awesome because of it.

Monday, May 17, 2010 at 11:58pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
And speaking of holes, how about Portland? I'm joking, I'm joking... but alas, I have spent far too much time in that particular city (Some of my grandparents live there) to truly appreciate its wonders. Although I am intimately, painfully aquainted with both the science museum and the hospital there. That came out far scarier than I intended it to... my grandparents work at the hospital. I've never had to go there for medical reasons. At least, none that I remember... moving on. But that does sound like all kinds of fun, Portland or no. I would totally appreciate the nerdy grammar jokes too, don't worry. And for the record, embrace your inner hipster. You know it's true. Me, I'm clinging desperately to my upcoming vacation to the Dominican Republic as a way to survive the next 4 weeks... think of it as a sunny, white sand life raft that's carrying me away from the Titanic shipwreck that was most of junior year.

Monday, May 17, 2010 at 11:52pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I have a feeling that my school's journalism group didn't go to Portland... as I've explained before, they aren't the most illustrious group of students. Just last week, I was pulled back in (I swear to god, it's like the mafia - once you're in, you can never get out. That one semester of newspaper will haunt me forever) to write a letter to the editor. They literally have to ask people to write these things, otherwise no one will. Sad, but true. I really love the LOTR references that keep showing up, by the way. Although if you're Gandalf and I'm a Ring Wraith, we're gonna have a problem at some point. That may be the nerdiest sentence I've ever written. All that I need to do is tag a "Shiny!" to the end of it to reach true legendary nerd status. Must go die in hole now.

Monday, May 17, 2010 at 11:47pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
And yes, the apocalypse does seem to be oddly romanticized by most forms of entertainment. I couldn't quite decide which horribly nerdy reference to put here to demonstrate the power of the world ending to spur declarations of love, so feel free to insert your own. For the record, though, my friends do have the capacity to make that chick from the second X-Men movie look like she just needs a quick nail trim. Which can be amusing, when not directed at you. I feel like some government official is going to stumble upon this post and kidnap my friends for use in some special high-class military operation. Could I be more geeky? I think not. Speaking of which, no need to explain the appeal of a bookstore to me. This is the girl who's obsessed with the smell of new books... trust me, I get it.

Monday, May 17, 2010 at 11:41pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
But yes, AP exams are now over, which is a beautiful thing. And after three solid days of avoiding end-of-year projects in favor of cheesy chick flicks (Letters to Juliet would have Love Story in the soundtrack just to mock me...) my brain has returned to semi-normal. I feel that I, too, should start giving random shout-outs to BriBri since he will no doubt read this post when it clogs up his news feed. Hi Brian! Now to turn my attention to other happy things. Like the fact that summer is finally only four weeks away, which may be the best thing I've ever heard in my entire life. Or the fact that the Spanish teacher I've passionately loathed all year has not been asked to return (What can I say, I'm evil and vindictive. I wasn't even going to have her next year, and I still wanted her gone). Or the fact that within the next week, I might even actually send you those pictures...

Monday, May 17, 2010 at 11:36pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
So, your prediction about me being held hostage by AP testing came horribly, gruesomely true... Which is why I'm replying (almost) a month later. Yay for staring blankly at a textbook trying desperately to recall if you have, in fact, absorbed any knowledge at all the entire year. (Answer: Yes. On the AP US History Exam, you will know all about the Salem Witch Trials because you just watched The Crucible in English. You will know absolutely nothing else. Congratulations) In all honesty, I didn't even do that great a job of studying... instead, I sat around doing things to distract myself from how nervous I was about the fact that I didn't study. At one point, I even kidnapped one of my friends and made her go to Iron Man 2 with me. Because that's totally the best way to prepare for the AP Bio exam...

Tuesday, April 20, 2010 at 1:31am EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
So I'll actually write out our normal epic wall posts in a few days when I'm feeling marginally less overloaded/bitchy/generally homicidal (Welcome to Mondays. Look, I love parentheses too.) but your post about Zac Efron required immediate response: I think a part of my soul just died. That is all. Except, because it's me, that's never all. Number one: to the writers of that article, Zac Efron should never be equated to chocolate - that is heresy. Number two: Captain Reynolds/Hammer trumps Troy Whatever-the-hell-his-last-name-was-who-couldn't-sing-or-act. Every time. Number three: In defense of Zac Efron, there has only ever been and will only ever be one true "man-bangs", and his name is Chase Crawford. His man-bangs make Zac look like he has a buzz-cut. Okay, I'm all good now (True confession: When I first read the sentence about tween sensation, I thought that Justin Beiber had been on Firefly, and I almost cried. So somehow, Zac Efron was actually an improvement).

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.

I'm giving them a death glare as I type, as they bounce up and down over my fence. Not quite as annoying as freshmen, but close. So close. And now my dogs are trying to maul the neigbors' dogs. Through the fence. Brilliant. Okay, that about sums up my current thrilling life. Your flowery diction is forgiven. And I don't know who the guy on my profile is, actually. He crashed my picture at the last minute...

Seena Burns wrote on your timeline.
So I read something interesting about writing on design on the internet. Basically the way to be listened to is not to write for other people, but to write for yourself. But that's all intuitive. What jumped out at me was one person's recommendation to simply have the balls to piss people off. Not like just for kicks, but when you don't like something, don't hold back because other people do.

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:38am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Regarding your eerie silence: That sobbing noise you hear in the background? Those are my mother's tears of joy over the fact that she will no longer have to stay up until 4 in the morning. I translate the mountain of tissues around her as meaning that the offer to have you stay over still stands, and is now a permanent monument (She's not actually crying... I hope...) And no, my family's intent is not to kill John Connor. It is to prevent Frodo from destroying the one ring in the fires of Mordor, and to return the ring to our master, Sauron. Because that was a totally balanced and normal sentence (Sorry. I got another fascinating commentary on my last name the other day, and I couldn't resist. Did you know that the Nazgul are also known as Ring Wraiths? Becuase that was so totally news to me... *Excessive sarcasm alert*)

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:32am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I'm definitely calling prom "The Apocalypse" from now on. It's much better than my previous working title: "The Dread Event In Which I Will Inevitably Do Something Huumiliating And Potentially Life Threatening Like Trip On A Shrubbery And Impale Myself On My Own Shoe". Flows better, no? Oh god, now I'm visualizing you with green hair and strangely orange skin (Don't even get me started on the Oompa Loompas from the remake. If you don't sing the Oompa Loompa song, then you aren't an Oompa Loompa. Sorry). And like I said, my parents so don't care if you're sane... I think that, since I've told them that you understand over 50% of the random nonsense that comes flying out of my mouth, they've just assumed that you're at least partially unhinged. After all, I believe they think that I'm not just unhinged, my door has been blown halfway around the world by a hurricane of crazy.

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:23am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
It's not so much of a raised eyebrow when I hear about how Taylor Swift aspires to be a symbol of adultery as it is an attempt to not hunt her down and poison, stab, or brand her (Which is basically what happened to the three characters she's attempting to romanticize... would serve her right. I'm so tolerant.) The problem is that if I criticize her for the fact that she can't sing, then I'm being hypocritical. But I don't feel bad at all for mocking her over the fact that apparently she's unaware that if Romeo had ever tried to talk to Juliet's dad, the response would have been a sharp, pointy sword, not, "Sure! I'll put decades of fueding behind me because you saw my underage daughter at a party and thought she was pretty. Go tell her to pick out a white dress! This is the happiest day of my life!" Yes, I know that wasn't in Shakespearean English, but that's partially the point.

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:19am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
But seriously, if you ever get the chance, watch "Pushing Daisies". There are pies, bees, reanimation, bizarre deaths, the geekiest wordplay out there since the termination every Joss Whedon show on the planet, an awesome British narrator, a golden retriever, a pig, and Kristen Chenoweth. What more could you want from a t.v. show? And for the record, you clearly haven't met my dog. Not only is he fairly sure that he's technically a person, but he's equally sure that you aren't. He believes that he exists on a higher plane than the rest of the world, I'm fairly sure. He might actually be worth like 10 people. (The creepiest part of all of this? I may be exaggerating my dog's overinflated opinion of himself, but I swear that I've caught him sitting there, watching t.v. before. It's eerie.) And for the record, if my dog takes over, I'm fleeing to Costa Rica.

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:10am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Ugh, clothing-food. It sounds simultaneously delicious and disgusting, which I suppose is the point. Of course, considering my food OCD (and general OCD), I doubt I'd be that keen on eating mittens. Of course, now that you've mentioned death I'm tempted to compose some deep and meaningful epigraph that fully conveys the immensity of what you tried to accomplish. It may take a while; "Here lies Jason He died a gruesome death strangled by mutant french toast mittens but it was in the pursuit of science!" just doesn't seem to appropriately convey the gravity of the situation. And of course, there's a whole other one to right about your show-induced gooification (that's totally a word).

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 2:04am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Meyer and manatees? Really? I used to adore those plump little marine animals... now, whenever I see them, I'll just wonder why they aren't glittering, or awkwardly quoting "Wuthering Heights". And yes, I know that Meyer-bashing is just as much of a cliche as the Twilight frenzy, but in my defense, I have actually read all of her books... I think that they're actually sitting in my room somewhere, gathering dust. The same dust that any self-respecting vampire would turn into if he ever ventured out into the sun. But you're right, all rhetorical devices should probably be abandoned in wall posts: all roads inevitably lead back to either symbolism or sonnets, two things that I truly despise. I suppose that nixes my plans for writing an entire post that consisted only of hyperboles and onomatopoeia. Of course, half of what I say is hyperbole anyhow, so maybe it doesn't matter.

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 1:57am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
It's true. There once was a time when I actually found them endearing. Now, I find their beady little eyes, twitchy noses, and bushy tails to be distinctly menacing. And I blame COSMOS for this. Once, I loved squirrels. Now, I would probably cross a street to avoid drawing close to one. I think that they can sense that the tides have turned. They're watching. Always watching... I just reread that last paragraph and realized that I sounded even more mentally unbalanced than usual. How closely does your mother peruse your profile? No matter. You aren't a squirrel (that I'm aware of), so there shouldn't be a problem. And speaking of animals that I used to like...

Tuesday, March 9, 2010 at 1:52am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
So you'll be pleased to know that I've finally figured out the most dramatic change that last summer wrought in my life. Shockingly, it's not the fact that I'm now willing to become a felon just to reunite with the people I met (I do love the concept of COSMOS working against the world instead of for it. Nerd Camp Gone Wrong. Sounds like a straight-to-DVD movie. Or an episode of Eureka. For the record, dibs on the "Cluster 1" tramp stamp). Nor is it the fact that I now know several people who, for whatever reason - possibly mental illness - findy my nerdy snark endearing. As opposed to most of my school and swim friends, who just tell me to shut up when I go off on a truly trippy, geeky tangent. It's not even the fact that every time I see a frozen yogurt store or hear "Down" on the radio, I automatically look for the rest of the cluster. No, what I recently realized, was that many months ago, before COSMOS occurred... I actually liked squirrels.

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 2:23am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Also, did you get things worked out with you mom? And by "things" I refer to assuring her that I'm not (generally) a psychopath, and that I can get you home after the dance? Okay, so I know I said that I wasn't going to try to break your record, but Brian assured me that he wasn't a ninja, and my competitive side kicked in. I reclaim my old tombstone, and now adorn it with some artfully strewn roses and a new engraving saying "Nice try, Jason..." Of course, one of these days I'm going to just run out of random things to think of in my frightening mind, and subsequently post on your wall. "One of these days" naturally meaning, "when I'm actually in that grave we keep talking about". And yes, I was the White Witch in that scenario. Of course, with the soundrack to "Wicked" playing in the background, I've reformed. Now I want to be Elphaba. Where did I put those ruby slippers...?

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 2:18am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Of course, if your heart is set on those checkered pants, go for it. The head-shaving thing would also be new and interesting: any idea what in particular you would shave? I'm leaning towards a giant, rabid squirrel. Why do rodents always pop back up in these conversations? They're like some wall post infestation that we can't get rid of. But back to actual clothing: yeah, everyone seems to say rent a tux. Also, one of my friends has developed a bizarre fixation on you wearing a gold vest. If any of this appeals, go for it. If sweat pants and your old cosmos shirt appeal, go for it (though that would make for some truly unique and original pictures, I must say). Also, I don't know how far you've gotten on signing your life away to my school district, but I think that those forms are due on Thursday... just an update.

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 2:10am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
And now, to prom. Thank you for that lovely sweat visual... I almost felt like a needed to go take a shower after just reading that. Regarding friends: generally lovely people, yes. Tend to get a little overdramatic and carried away over the slightest thing, making prom an occasion worthy of a full on emotional breakdown? Also yes. Hence my fear. You'll be pleased to know that only a tiny, evil little sliver of myself was even remotely tempted to say that guys at my school buy suits make from the exact same fabric as their date's dress. Because flowery ruffles would have been a fashion statement for the ages. I am not so cruel... and after much inquiry, and some Ivy-style facebook stalking of my senior friends, the consensus appears to be that a rented tux is the way to go. Although, if I'm being honest, I don't really care what you wear as long as it doesn't incorporate those Dutch pants or Johnny Weir's skating outfit.

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 2:02am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I'm so glad that someone else noticed the fact that they'd totally ripped off Davy Jones for the cover - I thought of that the second I saw it. And there goes that Pirates theme... I have an ugly feeling that this could turn into a version of "The Game" - whoever hums the tune to themselves loses for the day. And I was indeed, a fairly patriotic (as Patriotic as I can get, which is to say, not much) American until the whole hockey situation today. Then, not so much. I know this Mad Men precedent of which you speak - my current show obsession is not with 50s America, though, but rather with pie. Specifically, the pie on "Pushing Daisies", which I just fell head-over-heels in love with in spite of the knowledge that it's already been cancelled for over a year. I've managed to work myself up to an almost-Firefly level of rage over the fact that it's no longer on the air...

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 1:55am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Eureka lives on for a fourth season; I think it might start again in the summer. Honestly, I'm just impressed that it keeps getting renewed, since I was always sort of under the impression that I was one of 2.5 people who actually watch that show (The other 1.5 being my dad and my dog. You can decide which is the 1 and which is the 0.5). Regarding sixth grade singing: I was not indie. I was not avante-garde. I was, to use your words, "just dreadful". People were just too polite to mention it. So now I restrict my singing to when I'm in the car blasting the radio. Then I can't hear my own voice. Plus, I've discovered that on some of the truly autotuned songs, they cover such a wide range of notes in the melody because of digital enhancement that you can pretty much sing whichever pitch you want and you'll be on key. This is comforting to me... If I had access to a studio and a guitar, I too could horribly misinterpret "Romeo & Juliet" and "The Scarlet Letter".

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 1:46am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Lederhosen + Yodeling = Recipe for not only no drama, but also no friends. Eclectic wouldn't even begin to describe it. Equally problamatic would be the breakfast food outfit; I would be concerned that if I was wearing, say, french toast (it's always french toast) mittens during a particularly dull class, I would get bored and start trying to eat them. Speaking of charming mental images... I'm tempted to start going into an alliterative mode after all this talk of marine animals and their literary counterparts. Walruses and Wordsworth! Dolphins and Dante! Fish and (god help me, we just finished this book and I hated it... every color in the rainbow should not have a deeper meaning. Every now and then, Gatsby should be wearing a pink suit because he genuinely like the color pink, not because his attempts at upper class life are tainted by his past) Fitzgerald!

Monday, March 1, 2010 at 1:38am EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
I'm on the fence about whether or not teenage girls are legally obligated to know the storyline of Pride and Prejudice, though. I mean, I know that I do, but the term "bookworm" has sort of been superglued to me since I was born... and let's face it, that book is more than a little wordy. And unrealistic. Which, interestingly, describes most of the books that I enjoy... hello, life of delusion. I think my favorite quote about Jane Austen is one where Mark Twain said that every time he read some of her work he wanted to dig up her grave and beat her with her own shinbone (I know that this totally sounds like something I would make up, but it's not, I swear. I'm paraphrasing, but this seriously is one of his quotes)

The campus of my high school is actually littered with petrified underclassmen... it looks kind of like the White Witch's courtyard in Narnia. And with that awesome mental image, I am done.

Saturday, February 20, 2010 at 7:41pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Speaking of hilarious costumes (I'm shooting for a new record in wall posts. Also, I so don't want to do homework right now, and this is way more fun) the dreaded prom season has descended upon my school... Run for your life! I jest... except that I really, really don't. My loathing of dances has reached something of a state of infamy, but I have some truly tenacious, semi-intimidating friends (You think I'm scary? You need to meet some of these people) who have assured me that I'm going, either of my own volition, or bound, gagged, and sedated. Yay! So I spent about two hours today trying on an assortment of dresses that ranged from "Makes me look like a fourty-year-old soccer mom" to "Makes me look like a really *expensive* hooker". Which was fun. But I did eventually find one which didn't make me look like a hooker or a linebacker, but did cost more than double my mother's wedding dress. She's very proud.

Yeah, now visualize that on ice. It would be so, so bad. Although, I imagine it would actually be pretty funny to watch. Just not so funny for me. So I switched from choir to Leadership.

Saturday, February 20, 2010 at 7:16pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
After your comment, I have officially decided to start my own college in Antarctica. I could study with the penguins. It would be thrilling to hear their take on Shakespeare. I just reread that sentence and realized what a nerd I am. Shockingly, I don't care. Sadly, studying with penguins would probably actually be preferable to studying with some of my classmates. Somehow my "I am Switzerland" memo seems to have not been properly distributed this year, which means that I've been subjected to a whole truckload of catty teenage girl drama. Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.

And speaking of driving, who ever said that you had to drive well to get a license? I have a friend who drove on the wrong side of the road and still got hers (two tests later, though... the DMV does have some standards, and I believe the ability to tell right from left is still one of them). So, understandably, the thought of you behind the wheel of a car is not nearly as frightening as the thought of some of my friends...

Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at 5:16pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Hmm, my wintertime escapades (sounds kind of like a figure-skating show... Stephanie on Ice!) have been fairly nonexistent... mostly swimming, and avoiding doing homework, which is what I'm doing right now. I've read a couple of books (how unusual for me), and I did go see Avatar, which was better than I thought it was going to be. Throw in a couple of exciting social events, including an edge-of-your-seat ornament exchange and a Harry Potter movie marathon, and you have my break thus far. Were I to gaze into my crystal ball, or read my tea leaves, or whatever, I would predict that the remaining days of break for me would be filled with much homework, applications for some summer programs, and both my mother and my piano teacher scolding me for not having accomplished more. Your turn to share your "winter escapades", if you will. Any exciting gifts? (I recieved a scarf that bore a remarkable resemblance to a strip of bacon. It was thrilling.)

Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at 5:09pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Swimming is joyful fun, especially the morning practices where the pool deck is icy and the kickboards are literally frozen over... but it is true, I was able to justify every piece of pie and chocolate that I ate during Christmas. Not gonna lie, your description of your Disneyland experience calls to mind that scene from "Over the Hedge" where the squirrel drinks soda, and the world stops spinning. And it's true, I have yet to have a negative Disneyland experience - the closest I've come was the overnight bus trip down there for my choir trip in 6th grade. We were supposed to sleep on the way there and wake up energized and ready to enter the park, but the teacher insisted on playing some exceptionally loud, poorly written scifi movie on the bus, so I woke up every 15 minutes to the sound of gunfire. Fun stuff. I can't believe you've only been once! My family goes to Disneyland at least once a year... it's almost a religious thing at this point.

Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at 5:03pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
And yes, Atticus is also out. Tom and Jim are fine, Huck is not. Scout is in, but only if you're naming a dog. Chief Bromden isn't even a good name for a dog. And now this is making me think of school, which is exactly what I've been avoiding for all of break... I'm glad you got to see the Firefly reference... it was hilarious, because I wasn't actually looking for it, I was just watching the show, and at first I was wondering if I'd turned the wrong thing on by mistake. There was a more subtle "two by two, hands of blue" reference a while ago that was also entertaining. I'm glad Nathan Fillion has a new show where I can watch him, but I secretly still hope that by some miracle, Firefly will be brought back. Impossible, I know, and yet.

Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at 4:57pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
It's a good thing you explained your bizarre formatting, because otherwise I might have thought that the poetry thing was intentional, and would have been forced to respond with a sonnet... I hate sonnets. So much that in my creative writing class last year, when we had to write a sonnet, I wrote one about how much I hate them. It was an amazing poem... But I digress. Puppy chow, muddy buddies... tomayto, tomahto. Does it matter when it's so amazingly tasty? And also, one of the only food items that I have the ability to cook? I'm going to wind up subsisting off of desert items when I have to cook for myself, I can just tell...

Tuesday, December 29, 2009 at 4:53pm EST
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Let me start off by saying that you are probably the only person I know who could find a way to use the word "basil" not once but twice over the course of a wall post. My condolences to your garden herbs. Does this mean that you, too, had snow fall upon your town? It was fairly amazing here in Danville, the land of snows-maybe-once-every-seven-years. The downtown looked postcard-perfect, and the high school was beautiful... until the freshmen started throwing snowballs. At which point I adopted my famed "you hit me and you die" facial expression. Also, snow is amazing and gorgeous, until it starts to melt, at which point I hate it with the fiery passion of a thousand suns as it drips off of the roof and onto my head. This makes my desire to go to a college on the east coast something of a problem... though if I go somewhere cold enough, the snow might never melt.

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Anyhow, what else... I have mastered the art of making Muddy Buddies, which are delicious. I read "East of Eden" for English, and reached the conclusion that I am very happy that my parents didn't name me Cathy. I also pissed off the rest of my reading group by requesting that we read "East of Eden" in the first place, as it is a mere 600 pages. Their fault for not standing up to me and demanding a shorter classic to read. My school has started a Harry Potter Club, which I found hilarious until I began to worry that it would establish the precedent for a Twilight Club... That's pretty much all that comes to mind right now. Oh, and I'm going to see RENT tomorrow night in the city, which I am incredibly excited for (It's the touring production with Adam Pascal and Anthony Rapp - the original Roger and Mark. Eek!).

Saturday, October 10, 2009 at 8:01pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
And not to brag, but I have a camp story that trumps your raccoon infestation, awesome as it sounds. I have a "This one time at Girl Scout camp..." story that involves a skunk by the name of Frick. In case you were wondering, the "They're more afraid of you than you are of them" principle of wild animals does not apply to Frick. Frick does not fear you. Frick does not fear the camp counselors armed with flashlights. Frick does not fear anyone. "Glee" = pure awesomeness. I have been in love with it since they aired the pilot after the AI finale, and I swear it gets better each episode. Although the one with football and "Single Ladies" is probably my favorite so far. And yes, I basically started jumping up and down and screaming when Dr. Horrible showed up on the screen, startling awake the rest of my family, who had all been lulled to sleep by the many dull acceptance speeches.

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
hola, person to whom I have not spoken in the teenage girl equivalent of forever. For the record, I want credit for the fact that it took me six days of being trapped at home, sick and bored out of my mind, before I resorted to writing epic essays on your wall. Not to dwell on my suffering or anything, but I'm basically the worst person ever at being sick... I get bored easily. Anyhow, how are things with you? Basically, I'm really bored, and all out of tv shows and makeup work, so i'm taking it out on your poor wall. I'm thwarted somewhat by the fact that, being sick, nothing of interest has happened in about a week. maybe the illness is killing my imagination too. either way, i'm fresh out of ideas that don't involve rodents and/or starbucks, so for the first time in forever, this will be a one post message... hooray!

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Haha, I'm glad I've got you laughing at people who mispronounce "Wraith" now too... pretty much everyone in my grade knows about that issue. We'll have a sub in some class, and she'll go, "Is Stephanie Wrath here?", and the entire class will burst out laughing... while she sits there looking confused. Poor substitute... if only they could speak the english language (Just to vent for a minute: There is an *I* in that word! Did it suddenly turn invisible and I missed it? Why does everyone seem to think that it's a silent letter? Who ever heard of a silent "i"). Ok, I'm done. And I'm sure that when you respond, you will have found some word in which the "i" is silent. I don't care... "wraith" is not that word. The good news is that I'll always be able to determine whether someone has read The Lord of the Rings by how the pronounce my name. The bad news is, I don't really care. By the way, totally with you on the Chubbers thing.

Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
start with something along the lines of "It started out as just another summer romance. But it would become much, much more..." Ok, not exactly an accurate rendition (I'm pretty sure that even I, who will read just about anything, wouldn't read a book with that back cover), but you get my point. I do have a weak defense for the whole "quote" mishap. I was typing how I talk, but because I too am a grammar nazi, I added the punctuation. Hence, redundancy. However, no punch coming your way, due to the prolonged time it took me to respond. And speaking of ice breakers, name games, bonding, and teaching (Oh my!) I just spent the entire day at freshman orientation, doing those exact things with freshmen... half of whom were taller than me... no comment. With regards to the whole credits thing... I only do it for easter eggs too. But those credits are LONG! You have to find something diverting to do, which is how I know that there's a character called "Sunburned Sailor" in Pirates 3.

Word limit. Again. Anyhow: one or two seasons, unlike virtually everything else that Joss Whedon has ever done, it actually does start to suck at a certain point. The first three seasons are awesome (Don't worry, I'm not biased at all because of the presence of Angel...) and then Riley shows up for seasons 4 and 5 and everything kind of goes to hell (no not-particularly-funny pun intended). And then Spike shows back up and Riley leaves, and there's a musical episode, and it's all good again for the last two seasons. I am, of course, basing this assesment of the show off of a highly detailed analysis of its writing, acting, and plot... not off of when the two hot vampires that I like appear in the story line. Of course not - that would be wildly unprofessional and immature. But yes, to truly be a Whedon fan, at least some amount of Buffy-watching is necessary. You actually kind of went at it backwards. Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
There's a word limit on wall posts... who knew? Anyhow, where was I... oh, yeah. See, I've been trying to gradually revert from COSMOS sleep hours (midnight-ish to seven) to my normal sleep hours at home during the summer (where I go to bed fairly close to ten) in the hopes of preparing myself for a week and a half from now, when I have to start waking up at 4:45 again for swim practice... fun stuff. Plus, my dad and I have been trying to catch up on all the episodes of Eureka I missed (Nothing says father-daughter bonding like watching an obscure scifi show together). So I employ this special method of being on Facebook in sporadic, 10 minute chunks throughout the day. Which, of course, means that instead of chatting with everyone, I instead leave wall posts the length of the seventh Harry Potter book...

Tuesday, August 4, 2009 at 5:15pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Yeah, probably a good generalization, much like my favorite generalization: Avoid twitchy looking potentially rabid squirrels with messed-up tails. I saw a perfectly normal looking squirrel yesterday, and I still wouldn't go anywhere near it... I fear that this could become a permanent phobia. And with regard to the disgusting slime that they try to pass off as good, it's not both... it's one or the other (I highly reccomend the coffee for the maximum test of your gag reflex). And not the bar (I eat the bars all the time, as they aren't slimy... and appear to be inanimate), the goo, or gu, or however they spell it. It comes in these little, innocent-looking packets, and my coaches assure me that they will help me swim fast. I don't trust them. But please, try one. In fact, I'll let you take a pass on the whole banana-in-two-bites thing if you'll videotape yourself eating one of the little coffee-goo packets.

Tuesday, August 4, 2009 at 2:40pm EDT
Steph Wraith wrote on your timeline.
Oh, well heart attacks are generally a bad thing, so let's try to avoid one of those. And as far as working out my gag reflex goes, try those Powerbar Goo things. The coffee and chocolate flavors are wonderfully nauseating... I'm pretty sure that they're made from the same stuff as that prop slime they use in movies about aliens. I have no idea why no one else ever seems to be online at the same time as me - I have a theory that at the same time that I sign on to facebook, everyone I want to talk to signs off. So sad...

Monday, January 12, 2009 at 10:56pm EST
Seena Burns wrote on your timeline.
A test of the Archimedes heat ray was carried out in 1973 by the Greek scientist Ioannis Sakkas. The experiment took place at the Skaramagas naval base outside Athens. On this occasion 70 mirrors were used, each with a copper coating and a size of around five by three feet (1.5 by 1 m). The mirrors were pointed at a plywood mock-up of a Roman warship at a distance of around 160 feet (50 m). When the mirrors were focused accurately, the ship burst into flames within a few seconds. The plywood ship had a coating of tar paint, which may have aided combustion.[32] Sounds like we just might be able to burn some stuff… assuming we have access to 70 copper coated mirrors that are 1.5 by 1 m… http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,908175,00.html?promoid=googlep

Sunday, September 14, 2008 at 2:49pm EDT
Calvin Hu wrote on your timeline.
Hanners is far more adorable than Elliot. However, Marten is pretty damn awesome, in his awkward little way. As for music, QC is all over the place. They touch on metal, which you probably aren't interested in, super-indie stuff, are in love with Stephen Malkmus, who was a part of Pavement, some more electronic stuff (Brian Eno, who is super ambient. Check out Music for Airports to see what I mean.) If you want, look up LCD Soundsystem or TV on the Radio. They're in my iTunes somewhere, I just never got around to listening to them. Ooh. And Joshua Radin has a new album out - Simple Times. The single is: I'd Rather Be With You. Edit: Arg. I hate repeated edits, but also, give me my reading!

Sunday, June 8, 2008 at 3:55pm EDT
Justin Koehler wrote on your timeline.
I didn't REALLY do that much studying from the book, except taking a diagnostic test and going over the plant stuff, which I'm surprised that we never really learned... most of the questions I thought were pretty much common-sensical (like if the white blood cell count is down, what can you infer... ). Overall I thought I got about 65/80 problems correct; I left 5 blank, guessed on about 10... so I feel pretty confident. I'm sure that after Bio AP this will be super easy for us. Speaking generally, it's nice to just have a sense of what these SATII tests are all about.

nice to hear from you, jason =D how's summer? anyways, um...xcountry is somewhat serious, not really though. There are going to be people who's faster than you (not me, i'm a slug) that's on varsity. We usually did like, 2 times less than the junior varsity people and we can take it easier than most people. Join! it'll be hella fun xD cause teresa and julia are doing field hockey...(darn them...) but i have a friend who did both cross country and field hockey (even though they were in the same season) you're doing band next year, right?
